title: 107_hr1992
content: The Act titled "Internet Equity and Education Act of 2001" allows an exception to the 50 percent correspondence course limitations. The Internet Equity and Education Act of 2001 amends the definition of Institution of Higher Education for Title IV purposes to exempt courses offered via telecommunications from being considered correspondence courses for institutions participating in certain loan programs with a low cohort default rate. The Internet Equity and Education Act of 2001 amends the definition of Institution of Higher Education for Title IV purposes to exempt courses offered via telecommunications from being considered correspondence courses for institutions participating in certain loan programs with a low cohort default rate. The act requires institutions to notify the Secretary of their election to qualify as an institution of higher education through specific provisions within 90 days, subject to the Secretary's assessment of potential risks to Federal funds and program integrity. The Internet Equity and Education Act of 2001 amends the definition of Institution of Higher Education for Title IV purposes to exempt certain courses from being considered correspondence courses for institutions participating in specific loan programs with a low cohort default rate. The Internet Equity and Education Act of 2001 amends the definition of Institution of Higher Education for Title IV purposes to exempt institutions with a low cohort default rate from certain requirements. The institution was notified that their election would pose a significant risk to Federal funds and program integrity. SEC. 3 amends the definition of a week of instruction for eligible programs. SEC. 4 addresses incentive compensation. SEC. 4. Incentive compensation prohibited under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Higher Education Act of 1965 prohibits institutions from making incentive payments based on enrollment or financial aid success to individuals involved in student recruitment or admission activities, with exceptions for third-party service providers with no control over admissions or financial aid decisions. The Higher Education Act of 1965 prohibits incentive payments based on enrollment or financial aid success for individuals involved in student recruitment or admission activities, with exceptions for third-party service providers. These providers must not pay employees based on securing enrollments or financial aid, and fixed compensation is exempt from incentive payment regulations. The Higher Education Act of 1965 prohibits incentive payments for student recruitment or admission activities. Amendments include repealing paragraph (20) of section 487(a) and amending section 487(c)(1) by replacing "paragraph (2)(B)" with "paragraph (3)(B)". SEC. 5. EVALUATION AND REPORT. Institutions of higher education covered by requirements related to course of study or distance education programs. Institutions of higher education must comply with the Secretary of Education's requests for information on changes in instruction, programs, enrollment, and financial aid for students in nontraditional formats. The Secretary of Education is required to conduct a study and submit a report to Congress on the effects of amendments on institutions of higher education providing distance learning opportunities and program integrity. The study will also focus on changes in instruction methods for distance education courses. The Secretary of Education must report to Congress on the impact of amendments on higher education institutions offering distance learning, including details on instruction methods, student enrollment, financial aid, and student outcomes. Additionally, any violations of the Higher Education Act of 1965 must be reported, along with actions taken by the Department of Education. The Department of Education must report to Congress on the impact of amendments on higher education institutions offering distance learning, violations of the Higher Education Act of 1965, actions taken against violators, and recommendations for improving provisions to accommodate nontraditional educational opportunities in Federal student assistance programs. SEC. 6. Learning Anytime Anywhere Partnerships: Allows funds from the Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education to be used for continuation grants if funds are not appropriated for a fiscal year. SEC. 7. Implementation: Ensures no delay in the effective date of the amendments and exempts them from certain implementing regulations. Attest: JEFF TRANDAHL, Clerk.
